channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: For Shooting Suspect, a Long Path of Conflict From Afghanistan to America
item.description: Rahmanullah Lakanwal was among the Afghans who came to the United States after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan. Earlier, he served in a paramilitary unit that worked with U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Hamed Aleaziz and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Uses National Guard Shooting to Cast Suspicion on Refugees
item.description: President Trump claimed there were “a lot of problems with Afghans,” without providing evidence, as his administration announced that it was implementing new immigration guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump held a video call to thank members of the military for their service on Thursday.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Worst Fire in Decades Fuels Scrutiny of Safety Lapses
item.description: The authorities said flammable netting and foam boards may have fueled the city’s deadliest blaze in nearly 80 years, killing more than 90 and prompting arrests.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong, Tiffany May and Keith Bradsher

item.title: ‘No Alarm Went Off’: Hong Kong Fire Survivor Recounts Harrowing Escape
item.description: Many windows were covered, preventing residents from seeing the fire and smoke, one survivor said.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A survivor said the fire moved with terrible speed as it seemed to climb up the tall apartment towers and then jump across the gaps between them.

item.title: U.S. Has Limited Knowledge of Those It Kills in Boat Strikes
item.description: The U.S. military has killed more than 80 people since the campaign began in early September. But it does not know who specifically is being killed.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lessons of the long war against terrorism appear to have been cast aside as the Trump administration attacks boats in the Caribbean and the eastern Pacific that it says are carrying drugs.

item.title: Why Is the U.S. Threatening Venezuela?
item.description: Venezuela doesn’t play a large role in the drug trade to the United States, so what is motivating the massive military buildup? Julian E. Barnes, who reports on intelligence and international security, discusses the issues with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Katrin Bennhold, Nikolay Nikolov, Leila Medina, Lazaro Gamio, Samuel Granados and Stephanie Swart

item.title: U.S. to Press Europe and Other Allies on Immigration, Document Says
item.description: American diplomats were told to raise U.S. concerns about “violent crimes associated with people of a migration background.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: Where the Waters Are Rough, a Fishing Town Confronts Trump’s Priorities
item.description: First, Newport, Ore., lost its Coast Guard rescue chopper. Then came the swirl of rumors and evidence that Immigration and Customs Enforcement was coming to town.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Ruth Fremson

item.title: Gen X-ers Have Money to Spend. Why Are Retailers Ignoring Them?
item.description: Three in four Americans ages 45 to 60 say they expect to overspend for the holidays. They’re “sort of like the glue within the consumer spectrum.”
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Janne Iivonen

item.title: Black Friday Deals Can Put People in Debt. Here’s How to Manage It.
item.description: The convenience of one-click purchases and “buy now, pay later” loans is making it easier for people to shop — and shop and shop — during the holidays.
item.dc:creator: Juli Fraga and Connie Chang
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristen Conti, 60, sought help after spending more than $1,000 on Labubu dolls and Christmas decorations. She has over $50,000 in credit card debt.

item.title: I’ve Written About Loads of Scams. This Phone Scam Almost Got Me.
item.description: The caller ID said “Chase Bank,” and the man on the line said I might be a victim of fraud. His supervisor would explain.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wilson

item.title: Did a Brooklyn Couple Kill a Neighbor’s Trees for a Better View in Maine?
item.description: Maine’s Board of Pesticides Control says two summer residents poisoned a neighbor’s trees so the couple, both Martha Stewart associates, could have a harbor view. They deny it.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson and Sophie Park
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: 11 Women, 9 Dogs, Not Much Drama (and No Guys)
item.description: These retired women in Texas have been through infertility, illness, layoffs, addiction and disappointing marriages. Now they are trying to create a utopia just for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Miller and Shelby Tauber
item.media:description: Robyn Yerian, the founder of The Bird’s Nest near Dallas.

item.title: Penn & Teller’s Secret to a 50-Year Partnership
item.description: As their magic act hits 50 years, they’re bigger than ever. They say their secret is not to socialize. But misdirection is also their love language.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman and Roger Kisby
item.media:description: “There’s no one I trust more,” Jillette said of Teller, who said separately, “We always claim we are not friends, but of course we are.”

item.title: My Parents Expected to Be Retired. Instead, They Are Raising My Sister’s Kids.
item.description: My mom and dad joined the millions of Americans who parent their children’s children — a beautiful responsibility that comes at a high cost.
item.dc:creator: Frances Dodds
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jane with two of her grandchildren.

item.title: A Professor’s Final Gift to Her Students: Her Life Savings
item.description: Cris Hassold, a professor at New College of Florida for 50 years, left a mark on her 31 favorite students. “I think about her almost every day,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders
item.media:credit: New College of Florida
item.media:description: Cris Hassold, center, in an undated photograph. She carved out an influential but complex legacy in a half-century of teaching at New College of Florida.

item.title: Sean Duffy Longs for the ‘Golden Days’ of Air Travel. What Was That Like?
item.description: Back in the ’50s and ’60s, passengers (well-dressed, of course, and with perfect manners) could count on hot meals on china, plenty of legroom, the occasional piano bar, even wool blankets. Those days are gone.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Pictorial Parade/Archive Photos, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Fewer people flew in the 1960s, which allowed airlines to use the extra space for lounges where people drank and socialized.

item.title: Trump Cut Europe Out of Ukraine Talks. Here’s How Europe Pushed Back.
item.description: European leaders were blindsided by President Trump’s 28-point-plan to end the Ukraine war, setting off a dash for influence.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Christopher F. Schuetze and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Secretary of State Marco Rubio in the Netherlands in June.

item.title: France Creates Voluntary Military Service as Europe Faces Russian Threat
item.description: The effort, aimed at young people, came after an army chief angered many by saying the country must accept the possible loss of “our children” in a future war.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Thomas Padilla/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Thursday in the French Alps, where he announced a paid, voluntary military service.

item.title: Putin Defends Witkoff Against Accusations of Pro-Russia Bias
item.description: The Russian leader called the U.S. special envoy “an intelligent man” who is properly representing his country in peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Gavriil Grigorov/Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media showed President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with Steve Witkoff in Moscow in August. The two are scheduled to meet again next week.

item.title: Carney Lifts Climate Laws for New Alberta Pipeline
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney reached a tentative deal with the province as part of his program to curb the country’s economic dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Todd Korol/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta on Thursday in Calgary.

item.title: In Turkey, Pope Seeks to Soothe an Ancient Christian Divide
item.description: In Istanbul, Pope Leo XIV will meet the patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church to show amity between two of the world’s largest Christian groups.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists light candles during a visit to the Theological School of Halki, an Orthodox seminary shuttered by the Turkish government.

item.title: Pope Leo Visits Turkey on His First Trip as Pontiff
item.description: The pope started his six-day trip, which will also include a visit to Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV at the Ataturk Mausoleum in Ankara, Turkey.

item.title: SNAP Helping Families Put Thanksgiving Dinner on the Table
item.description: SNAP benefits helped Leanna Nieves of Haverhill, Mass., buy Thanksgiving dinner for her family, but she used the day to set aside what have been chronic worries about the federal program.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leanna Nieves prepared a Thanksgiving meal with her friend Angelica, left, and Angelica’s daughter, Deannjellyk, at her home in Haverhill, Mass.

item.title: Gene Therapy Offer a Cure for Babies With the Deadly ‘Bubble Boy Disease’
item.description: “Bubble boy disease” was once a death sentence. A scientific breakthrough changed that.
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj
item.media:credit: Adam Amengual for The New York Times

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern, Architect Who Reinvented Prewar Splendor, Dies at 86
item.description: He designed museums, schools and libraries before winning international acclaim late in life for 15 Central Park West in Manhattan, hailed as a rebirth of the luxury apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Richard Perry/The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert A.M. Stern in 2007. Glowing reviews drove a stampede of celebrities to 15 CPW — the building he described as “my breakthrough” — overshadowing the competition from sleek glass towers that had been the rage in Manhattan early in the new millennium.

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern Is Still Dreaming of a Fresh New York
item.description: The sharp-tongued architect and professor built Manhattan’s most luxurious towers, but his new book shuttles from Billionaires’ Row to the Bronx. (Plus, what he thinks of Rem and Zaha.)
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago

item.title: The Uniquely American Heartbreak of Yet Another Tragedy
item.description: The National Guard members shot in Washington are the latest victims of a political violence permeating our society.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)
item.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press

item.title: Trump’s Greedy Thanksgiving
item.description: This year, it’s not about giving back; it’s about getting yours.
item.dc:creator: Molly Jong-Fast
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters

item.title: Sri Lanka on High Alert as Cyclone Death Toll Reaches 56
item.description: Heavy rainfall was forecast for nearly all of the island nation as Cyclone Ditwah churned northwest toward India.
item.dc:creator: Pamodi Waravita
item.media:credit: Eranga Jayawardena/Associated Press
item.media:description: Storm damage in Colombo, Sri Lanka’s capital, on Friday.

item.title: Louvre Raising Ticket Prices for Non-European Visitors
item.description: From Jan. 14, visitors to the museum from outside the European Economic Area will pay 45 percent more for entry to help finance its ambitious renovation plan.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Louvre is still on the mend after thieves broke into one of its galleries in October and stole about $100 million worth of jewelry.

item.title: Labubu and KPop Demon Hunters Join Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
item.description: Crowds in New York City bundled up to take in the latest version of a tradition that has run for nearly a century.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir and Vincent Alban
item.media:description: Pac-Man, near the beginning of the two-and-a-half-mile Thanksgiving Parade.

item.title: The British Public Thinks Immigration Is Up. It’s Actually Down, Sharply.
item.description: Net migration to Britain has fallen by almost 80 percent from its 2023 peak, according to data released on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images
item.media:description: Anti-migrant protesters outside a hotel in Scotland in August. Despite public perception, migrants who come ashore on small boats represent a fraction of overall immigration to Britain.
